resource.title: [PRD101i-EN] Kii Dissecting Balloon Market Overview

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to the Kii Dissecting Balloon Market Overview course! This course is narrated.

The purpose of this course is to inform you about the Kii Dissecting Balloon.

To ensure that this course is tailored to your specific Applied Medical location, please enter your location below:

For the U.S. team, please enter in RSM.

For the Europe team, please enter in AME.

So what is a hernia? It is the abnormal protrusion of an organ, such as the intestines, through a tear or opening in the weakened abdominal wall. To repair a hernia, the surgeon places the contents back in the abdominal cavity and closes the tear or opening either with sutures or mesh.

There are several types of hernias that occur.

Click on each to learn more.

Hiatal

The hiatal hernia occurs when the upper stomach squeezes through the hiatus, which is an opening in the diaphragm through which the esophagus passes.

Ventral or Incisional

The ventral or incisional hernia occurs at the site of a previous abdominal surgery.

Umbilical

The umbilical hernia occurs in the belly button.

Femoral

The femoral hernia occurs in the upper part of the thigh near the groin just below the inguinal ligament.

Inguinal

The inguinal hernia occurs when the abdominal cavity contents protrude through a weak area of lower abdominal wall in the groin region.

The most common types of hernias are inguinal hernias, which account for about 75% of all abdominal wall hernias. Inguinal hernias occur most commonly in males.

Often when surgeons perform surgery on a hernia site, they run into finding two hernias (bilateral) and thus need to create more working space by dissecting the second area to perform the procedure.

The most common types of hernias are inguinal hernias. Inguinal hernias occur most commonly in males.

Often when surgeons perform surgery on a hernia site, they run into finding two hernias (bilateral) and thus need to create more working space by dissecting the second area to perform the procedure.

Records of hernia occurrences go way back. Between 1500 and 400 B.C., some of the first groups to describe hernias were the Egyptians, Phoenicians, and Greeks. Then in the mid-1700s, during the Age of Dissection, the inguinal anatomy was explored. It was between 1883 and 1889 when the first effective open surgery to repair a hernia was performed, the Bassini Technique. A hundred years later in the 1980s, the soft surgical mesh was first used in hernia repairs called the Lichtenstein Technique. Between 1990 and 1991, the laparoscopic hernia repair techniques called TEP and TAPP were developed, and dissecting balloon devices were developed to assist the TEP procedure. Today, TEP is becoming more widespread as laparoscopic surgery pushes towards a more minimally invasive approach.

We will now discuss the differences between the TEP & TAPP approaches for inguinal hernia repair.

So, what are TEP and TAPP procedures and what are the differences?

TEP stands for totally extraperitoneal, which means that the procedure is performed entirely outside of the peritoneal cavity.

TAPP stands for transabdominal preperitoneal, which means that the procedure is performed through the peritoneal cavity as well as the preperitoneal space.

If you look at a side by side comparison, youll see what each has to offer.

A TEP approach begins with creating an infraumbilical incision and manually dissecting down to the posterior rectus sheath, whereas a TAPP approach begins with creating an infraumbilical incision, inserting a scope port, and insufflating the abdominal cavity.

Then with a TEP approach, the surgeon will dissect the extra peritoneal space to allow for insufflation of the preperitoneal space. The surgeon will replace the dissecting balloon with a blunt tip trocar for the scope entry and then insufflate the dissected preperitoneal space. The surgeon will also introduce ancillary trocar ports down the midline from the scope port for additional instrument use.

Whereas with a TAPP approach, the surgeon will place two additional ancillary ports on the right and left sides of the scope port, across the abdomen laterally. From within the abdomen, a peritoneal flap is created on the inner lining of the abdominal wall using energy to gain access within the preperitoneal cavity.

With a TEP approach, the surgeon will replace the dissecting balloon with a blunt tip trocar for the scope entry and then insufflate the dissected preperitoneal space. The surgeon will also introduce ancillary trocar ports down the midline from the scope port for additional instrument use.

As mentioned before, with a TAPP approach, the surgeon will insert two additional ancillary ports.

For a TEP approach, the hernia sac is identified and reduced, and the surgeon will place and secure the mesh in the preperitoneal space over the hernia opening.

For a TAPP approach, from the opening in the peritoneal flap, the hernia sac is dissected away from important landmarks and reduced or repositioned.

Mesh is then placed inside the peritoneal flap, spread out completely (no folds) within the preperitoneal space. Surgeons may then utilize a fixation tool (i.e., suture or tacker tool to place tacks on mesh). In the TAPP approach, the peritoneal flap is then sutured closed and the preperitoneal and abdominal cavities are de-sufflated. In the TEP approach, the weight of the abdominal wall layers will ensure the mesh stays collapsed between them to cover the repaired hernia sac opening. The mesh will stay within the patients abdomen.

For a TEP approach, the surgeon will desufflate and collapse the preperitoneal cavity with the mesh in place.

For a TAPP approach, the peritoneal flap is sutured closed against the mesh.

As we enter this market, the impact is two-fold.

Clinically, many surgeons use dissecting balloons to help aid in the dissection of the preperitoneal space while performing TEP procedures. Because of high prices, surgeons are likely to choose alternative options that do not require the use of dissecting balloons, which means physicians are forced to choose between costs and patient outcomes.

Economically, Medtronic has been the only U.S. competitor, which enables them to sell their dissecting balloons from $300 up to $600 on average. In regions, such as Europe, pricing is reduced, yet it is still relatively high.

Staying true to Applieds philosophy, we believe that by entering this market we can provide clinical benefits to surgeons and patients, such as our consistent quality-control process, as well as economic improvement by providing high quality devices.

U.S. Surgical was one of two companies selling dissecting balloons and was bought out by Tyco in 1998

In 1999, Origin was sold to U.S. Surgical

With Tyco owning these two companies, they became large enough to split into three smaller companies

Tyco Electric

Tyco Fire and Safety

And Tyco Healthcare which was renamed as its own company under Covidien

Covidien then owned the market of dissecting balloons for 10 years until they were bought out by Medtronic, who inherited the product line.

The US dissecting balloon market originally started with the Autosuture standalone distention balloons and trocars evolving to the Spacemaker modular dissection balloon systems with Spacemaker Plus, and then leading to creation of a full TEP hernia access kit with Spacemaker Pro.

Around 130,000 inguinal hernia repairs are performed in the US annually

Of those 130,000 procedures, around 60,000 of them are performed via the TEP approach using dissecting balloons for surgical access.

The market potential for the Kii dissecting balloon is based on the sales of Medtronics dissecting balloon models and modular systems, as they have had hold of the US DB market.

This graph represents the trends in inguinal hernia repair procedures over the past 5 years.

Open procedures on the overall have been declining with more adoption of minimally invasive approaches through laparoscopy as well as with the uptake in robotic surgery.

Robotic surgery data was primarily captured within the laparoscopic procedural volume realm up until 2016. Thereafter, robotic procedural volumes started to be captured separately in its own category for inguinal hernia repair surgery.

The table here showing the market potential for the Kii dissecting balloon is based on the sales numbers of Medtronics dissecting balloon models and modular systems over the past 3 years, as they currently have the largest hold on the US dissecting balloon market.

As we enter this market, the impact is two-fold.

Clinically, many surgeons use dissecting balloons to help aid in the dissection of the preperitoneal space while performing TEP procedures. Because of high prices, surgeons are likely to choose alternative options that do not require the use of dissecting balloons, which means physicians are forced to choose between costs and patient outcomes.

Economically, dissecting balloons have been increasing in price over the past several years.

Staying true to Applieds philosophy, we believe that by entering this market we can provide clinical benefit to surgeons and patients, such as our consistent quality-control process, as well as economic improvement by providing high quality devices.

So who performs hernia repairs? General surgeons are the primary surgeons who perform hernia repair procedures. However, surgeons who specialize in bariatrics, gastrointestinal, and colorectal specialties may also perform hernia specialties.

When visiting a facility and cross referencing cases you plan to attend with the OR board, it is important to keep in mind that most likely procedures will not be identified as TEP or TAPP procedures, but rather by the type of hernia procedure being performed. You should follow up and touch base with your surgeon on his or her case and what you should expect to see on his or her OR board schedule.

Surgeon targets for the Kii dissecting balloon product line include:

TEP practicing surgeons (especially TEP surgeons practicing at Ambulatory Surgery Centers)

Surgeons who are currently using a competitor dissecting balloon to gain access during TEP surgery

Surgeons using other methods such as blunt dissection to gain access during TEP surgery

And TEP surgeons who practice at Applied trocar accounts.

Surgeons who are not targets for this product line include those performing inguinal hernia repairs on the robot, or surgeons repairing hernias via the laparoscopic TAPP approach
So what components come with the Kii Dissecting Balloon? An introducer, an inflation bulb, a seal, a cannula, and a balloon make up the Kii Dissecting Balloon device.
The Kii Dissecting Balloon model numbers are shown here.

This is part of a 3-course series that consist of the following:

Kii Dissecting Balloon | Overview

Kii Dissecting Balloon | Product Profile and Competitors

Kii Dissecting Balloon | TEP & TAPP Procedural Profile
Thank you for completing this course. Please click the Finish button.
